We will continue to support care homes to deliver the highest possible level of service via

work in collaboration with contracts, brokerage, multi-agency safeguarding hub (MASH) and 
health colleagues to upskill and drive-up standards in care homes. 
In addition, we will support care homes to flex their offer in a changing market and ensure

17 Market Position Statement 2024 Homecare 
Cambridgeshire has 136 CQC registered homecare providers and funds 32,712 hours of 
homecare per week (March 2023 figures). Of the providers which have been rated by CQC, 
91% were found to be Good or Outstanding. This is above the national average of 89%. 
Homecare capacity is highly dynamic and difficult to measure across the entire market, so 
the Council uses proxy measures such as waiting times for care to determine if there are 
sufficiency areas. The most recent data suggests that sufficient capacity is available with 
minimal waits for care in Cambridgeshire. It should be noted that this is not always the case. 
Challenges remain in rural and hard to reach areas to provide sustainable and cost-effective 
care for people with complex needs.

answer:
If you're concerned about the costs of your home care in Cambridgeshire, you may be eligible for financial assistance through a financial assessment conducted by the council. This assessment will determine if the council can contribute to your care costs based on your financial circumstances.

- **Financial Assessment**: The council will evaluate your income, savings, capital, and any benefits you receive to determine your contribution towards care costs. If your capital or savings exceed £23,250, you will likely need to pay the full cost of your care.

- **Savings Threshold**: If your savings are below £23,250, you may qualify for financial assistance from the council. It's important to note that the value of your home is considered unless it is occupied by a partner, children under 18, or a disabled relative.

- **Self-Funding**: If you are a self-funder, you will be responsible for paying for your own care, but the council can assist you in finding a care provider and managing the contract for a fee.

**Next Steps**:
- Contact Cambridgeshire County Council to request a financial assessment. You can find more information and contact details on their website at [www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk](https://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk).
- Consider discussing your situation with a financial advisor or a social worker who can provide guidance based on your specific circumstances.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Cambridgeshire County Council's care and support information sheets at [this URL](https://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/residents/adults/organising-care-and-support/care-and-support-information-sheets).
